lexUnit.name: unify.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: make or become united or uniform.

sentence.text: The great Frankish leader who unified the confederacy into a powerful entity was Clovis , first of the Merovingian kings .
Then one tried to unify gravity with quantum mechanics , one had to introduce the idea of " imaginary " time .
And when their great Emperor Gia Long finally rose from the Mekong delta a century ago to unify all the peoples from Saigon to Hanoi , had n't he triumphantly renamed his new empire " Viet Nam " ?
However , the theme of unifying Germany by means of unifying Europe is at least two hundred years old .
Second to Henry Yevele , Wynford was an architect of genius who transformed and unified English building .
But why do physicists want to unify phenomena , should they try to , and do the data justify their claims ?

If the first quotation refers to a time when Strife is relatively dominant and things are over-scattered , the second perhaps refers to the over-action of Love , when things best kept separate are unified .

Northern Telecom Ltd has unified its data network products under the name Magellan , and has announced a cell-based networking switch designed to bring together data , speech , video and image networks .

The character Sarrasine in Balzac 's story is just a collection of traits which is arbitrarily unified through being called ` Sarrasine " .
Whereas the Ego seeks to divide and separate , love seeks to unify and heal .
A new sense of identity enveloped Greek peoples throughout the Aegean , thus commencing a movement to expand Greece and unify the disparate Orthodox populations .
